places.name: Crotone
places.description: a port city in Calabria, southern Italy. Founded c. 710 BC as the Achaean colony of Kroton it became a great Greek city, home of the renowned mathematician-philosopher Pythagoras.

persons.name: Hesiod
persons.description: An ancient Greek poet generally thought to have been active between 750 and 650 BC, around the same time as Homer. In c. 730–700 BC. he wrote a poem, called the Theogony, describing the origins and genealogies of the Greek gods.

persons.name: Homer
persons.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

persons.name: Hesiod
persons.description: An ancient Greek poet generally thought to have been active between 750 and 650 BC, around the same time as Homer. In c. 730–700 BC. he wrote a poem, called the Theogony, describing the origins and genealogies of the Greek gods.

persons.name: Homer
persons.description: Homer was a Greek poet who is believed to have written the epic poems, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

places.name: Anatolia
places.description: Also known as Asia Minor. A large peninsula in West Asia it is the western-most extension of continental Asia as it borders European Turkey.

persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

places.name: Ionia
places.description: Ionia was an ancient region on the western coast of Anatolia, to the south of present-day İzmir, Turkey. It consisted of the northernmost territories of the Ionian League of Greek settlements.

persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

places.name: Phoenicia
places.description: An ancient civilization originating in the coastal strip of the Levant region of the eastern Mediterranean, primarily located in modern Lebanon.

persons.name: Pindar
persons.description: An Ancient Greek lyric poet from Thebes. Of the canonical nine lyric poets of ancient Greece, his work is the best preserved.

persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

persons.name: Euclid
persons.description: An ancient Greek mathematician, geometer and logician. Considered the "father of geometry", he is chiefly known for the Elements treatise, which established the foundations of geometry that largely dominated the field until the early 19th century.

persons.name: Amasis II
persons.description: A pharaoh of the Twenty-sixth Dynasty of Egypt, the successor of Apries at Sais. He was the last great ruler of Egypt before the Persian conquest.

persons.name: Thales
persons.description: Ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Ionia, Asia Minor.

persons.name: Anaximander
persons.description: A philosopher who belonged to the Milesian school and learned the teachings of his master Thales. He succeeded Thales and became the second master of that school where he counted Anaximenes and, arguably, Pythagoras amongst his pupils.

persons.name: Thales

persons.description: A philosopher who belonged to the Milesian school and learned the teachings of his master Thales. He succeeded Thales and became the second master of that school where he counted Anaximenes and, arguably, Pythagoras amongst his pupils.

persons.name: Anaximenes
persons.description: Ancient Greek Pre-Socratic philosopher from Miletus in Anatolia. He was the last of the three philosophers of the Milesian School, after Thales and Anaximander. These three are regarded by historians as the first philosophers of the Western world.

persons.name: Anaximander
persons.description: A philosopher who belonged to the Milesian school and learned the teachings of his master Thales. He succeeded Thales and became the second master of that school where he counted Anaximenes and, arguably, Pythagoras amongst his pupils.

places.name: Miletus
places.description: Miletus was an ancient Greek city on the western coast of Anatolia, near the mouth of the Maeander River in ancient Ionia. Its ruins are located near the modern village of Balat in Aydın Province, Turkey.

persons.name: Plutarch
persons.description: Greek writer most famous for his parallel lives of Greek and Roman statesmen and military leaders.

persons.name: Archelaus
persons.description: an Ancient Greek philosopher, a pupil of Anaxagoras, and may have been a teacher of Socrates.

persons.name: Socrates
persons.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

persons.name: Euripides
persons.description: A tragedian of classical Athens.

persons.name: Pericles
persons.description: Athenian general and politician who supported the arts and literature.

places.name: Iran
places.description: Iran, also known as Persia and officially the Islamic Republic of Iran, is a country located at the crossroads of West, Central and South Asia.

persons.name: Lucretius
persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Aristotle

He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: Daimachus
persons.description: Probably: Daimachus, Greek diplomat and writer.

persons.name: Lysander
persons.description: A Spartan military and political leader. He destroyed the Athenian fleet at the Battle of Aegospotami in 405 BCE, forcing Athens to capitulate and bringing the Peloponnesian War to an end.

persons.name: Aristotle

He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. persons.name: SilenusCalatinus
persons.description: Sicilian Greek historian of Magna Graecia who wrote a history in Greek of Hannibal's campaign in Italy from 218 to 204 BC. His work is known only from fragments and borrowings by other authors.

places.name: Gos
places.description: Aegospotami is the ancient Greek name for a small river issuing into the Hellespont northeast of Sestos. According to Pliny and Aristotle, a meteor landed here in 467 BC after reports of a comet.

places.name: Thrace
places.description: Thrace is a geographical and historical region in Southeast Europe. Bounded by the Balkan Mountains to the north, the Aegean Sea to the south, and the Black Sea to the east, it comprises present-day southeastern Bulgaria, northeastern Greece, and the European part of Turkey, roughly the Roman Province of Thrace.

persons.name: Anaxagoras
persons.description: Greek Presocratic philosopher.

places.name: Klazomenai
places.description: An ancient Greek city on the coast of Ionia.

persons.name: Marcus TuilliusCicero
persons.description: a Roman statesman, lawyer, scholar, philosopher, writer and Academic skeptic

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

persons.name: Xenophon
persons.description: A Greek military leader, historian and philosopher, who was a student of Socrates. He recorded some of Socrates' philosophy. He is mainly remembered for his book Anabasis.

persons.name: Hermippus
persons.description: Hermippus of Smyrna. A Greek grammarian, philosopher and biographer. Author of Lives - an extensively quoted but now lost classical work.

places.name: Samos
places.description: A Greek island in the eastern Aegean Sea, separated from Turkey by the mile-wide Mycale Strait. It was the birthplace of mathematician Pythagoras and philosopher Epicurus.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.
